Composite Fermions in Fractional Quantum Hall Systems

John J. Quinn University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Tennessee 37996, USA ââ Arkadiusz WÃ³js University of Tennessee, Knoxville, Tennessee 37996, USA
and Wroclaw University of Technology, 50-370 Wroclaw, Poland
Abstract

The composite Fermion (CF) picture offers a simple intuitive way of understanding many of the surprising properties of a strongly interacting two-dimensional electron fluid in a large magnetic field. The simple way in which the mean field CF picture describes the low lying bands of angular momentum multiplets for any value of the applied magnetic field is illustrated and compared with the results of exact numerical diagonalization of small systems. The justification of the success of the CF approach is discussed in some detail, and a CF hierarchy picture of the incompressible quantum fluid states is introduced. The CF picture is used to understand the energy spectrum and photoluminescence of systems containing both electrons and valence band holes.

1 Introduction

The study of the electronic properties of quasi-two-dimensional (2D) systems has resulted in a number of remarkable discoveries in the past two decades [1]. Among the most interesting of these are the integral [2] and fractional [3] quantum Hall effects. In both of these effects, incompressible states of a 2D electron liquid are found at particular values of the electron density for a given value of the magnetic field applied normal to the 2D layer.

The integral quantum Hall effect (IQHE) is rather simple to understand. The incompressibility results from a cyclotron energy gap, ââÏcPlanck-constant-over-2-pisubscriptðð\hbar\omega_{c}, in the single particle spectrum. When all states below the gap are filled and all states above it are empty, it takes a finite energy ââÏcPlanck-constant-over-2-pisubscriptðð\hbar\omega_{c} to produce an infinitesimal compression. Excited states consist of electronâhole pair excitations and require a finite excitation energy. Both localized [4] and extended single particle states are necessary to understand the experimentally observed behavior of the magneto-conductivity [5].

The fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE) is more difficult to understand and more interesting in terms of new basic physics. The energy gap that gives rise to the Laughlin [6] incompressible fluid state is completely the result of the interaction between the electrons. The elementary excitations are fractionally charged Laughlin quasiparticles, which satisfy fractional statistics [7]. The standard techniques of many body perturbation theory are incapable of treating FQH systems because of the complete degeneracy of the single particle levels in the absence of the interactions. Laughlin [6] was able to determine the form of the ground state wave function and of the elementary excitations on the basis of physical insight into the nature of the many body correlations. Striking confirmation of Laughlinâs picture was obtained by exact diagonalization of the interaction Hamiltonian within the subspace of the lowest Landau level of small systems [8]. Jain [9], Lopez and Fradkin [10], and Halperin et al. [11] have extended Laughlinâs approach and developed a composite Fermion (CF) description of the 2D electron gas in a strong magnetic field. This CF description has offered a simple picture for the interpretation of many experimental results. However, the underlying reason for the validity of many of the approximations used with the CF approach is not completely understood [12].

The object of this review is to present a simple and understandable summary of the CF picture as applied to FQH systems. Exact numerical calculations for up to eleven electrons on a spherical surface will be compared with the predictions of the mean field CF picture. The CF hierarchy [13] will be introduced, and its predictions compared with numerical results. It will be shown that sometimes the mean field CF hierarchy correctly predicts Laughlin-like incompressible ground states, and that sometimes it fails.

The CF hierarchy depends on the validity of the mean field approximation. This seems to work well in predicting not only the LaughlinâJain families of incompressible ground states at particular values of the applied magnetic field, but also in predicting the lowest lying band of states at any value of the magnetic field. The question of when the mean field CF picture works and why [12] will be discussed in some detail. As first suggested by Haldane [8], the behavior of the pseudopotential Vâ(L)ðð¿V(L) describing the energy of interaction of a pair of electrons as a function of their total angular momentum Lð¿L is of critical importance. Some examples of other strongly interacting 2D Fermion systems will be presented, and some problems not yet completely understood will be discussed.

The plan of the paper is as follows. In sectionÂ 2 the single particle states for electrons confined to a plane in the presence of an applied magnetic field [14] are introduced. The integral and fractional quantum Hall effects are discussed briefly. Haldaneâs idea [8] that the condensation of Laughlin quasiparticles leads to a hierarchy containing all odd denominator fractions is discussed. In sectionÂ 3 the numerical calculations for a finite number of electrons confined to a spherical surface in the presence of a radial magnetic field are discussed. Results for a ten electron system at different values of the magnetic field are presented. In sectionÂ 4 the ideas of fractional statistics and the ChernâSimons transformation are introduced. In sectionÂ 5 Jainâs CF approach [9] is outlined. The sequence of Jain condensed states (given by filling factor Î½=nâ(1+2âpân)â1ððsuperscript12ðð1\nu=n(1+2pn)^{-1}, where nðn is any integer and pðp is a positive integer) is shown to result from the mean field approximation. The application of the CF picture to electrons on a spherical surface is shown to predict the lowest band of angular momentum multiplets in a very simple way that involves only the elementary problem of addition of angular momenta [15]. In sectionÂ 6 the two energy scales, the Landau level separation ââÏcPlanck-constant-over-2-pisubscriptðð\hbar\omega_{c} and the Coulomb energy e2/Î»superscriptð2ðe^{2}/\lambda (where Î»ð\lambda is the magnetic length), are discussed. It is emphasized that the Coulomb interactions and ChernâSimons gauge interactions between fluctuations (beyond the mean field) cannot possibly cancel for arbitrary values the applied magnetic field. The reason for the success of the CF picture is discussed in terms of the behavior of the pseudopotential Vâ(L)ðð¿V(L) and a kind of âHundâs ruleâ for monopole harmonics [12]. In sectionÂ 7, a phenomenological Fermi liquid picture is introduced to describe low lying excited states containing three or more Laughlin quasiparticles [16]. In sectionÂ 8 the CF hierarchy picture [13] is introduced. Comparison with exact numerical results indicates that the behavior of the quasiparticle pseudopotential is of critical importance in determining the validity of this picture at a particular level of the hierarchy. In sectionÂ 9 systems containing electrons and valence band holes are investigated [17]. The photoluminescence and the role of excitons and negatively charged exciton complexes is discussed. The final section is a summary.

Haldane cautioned that the validity of the hierarchy scheme at a particular level depended upon the QP interactions which were totally unknown.

Because two charged particles cannot occupy the same position, one particle never senses the magnetic field of other particles, but it does sense the vector potential resulting from their CS fluxes. The classical equations of motion are unchanged by the presence of the CS flux, but the quantum statistics of the particles are changed unless Î±ð¼\alpha is an even integer.

For the two particle system, the vector potential associated with the CS flux ar2â(r1)subscriptasubscriptr2subscriptr1\bi{a}_{\bi{r}_{2}}(\bi{r_{1}}) depends only on the relative coordinate r=r1âr2rsubscriptr1subscriptr2\bi{r}=\bi{r}_{1}-\bi{r}_{2}. where Ïmsubscriptðð\psi_{m} is the solution with Î±=0ð¼0\alpha=0 (i.e. in the absence of CS flux). If Î±ð¼\alpha is an odd integer, Boson and Fermion statistics are interchanged; if Î±ð¼\alpha is even, no change in statistics occurs and electrons are transformed into composite Fermions with an identical energy spectrum.

The Hamiltonian for the composite particle system (charged particles with attached flux tubes) is much more complicated than the original system with Î±=0ð¼0\alpha=0. What is gained by making the CS transformation? The answer is that one can use the âmean fieldâ approximation in which Aâ(r)+aâ(r)Arar\bi{A}(\bi{r})+\bi{a}(\bi{r}), the vector potential of the external plus CS magnetic fields, is replaced by Aâ(r)+â¨aâ(r)â©Ardelimited-â¨â©ar\bi{A}(\bi{r})+\left<\bi{a}(\bi{r})\right>, where â¨aâ(r)â©delimited-â¨â©ar\left<\bi{a}(\bi{r})\right> is the mean field value of aâ(r)ar\bi{a}(\bi{r}) obtained by simply replacing Ï±â(râ²)=ðâ â(râ²)âðâ(râ²)italic-Ï±superscriptrbold-â²superscriptðbold-â superscriptrbold-â²ðsuperscriptrbold-â²\varrho(\bi{r}^{\prime})=\psi^{\dagger}(\bi{r}^{\prime})\psi(\bi{r}^{\prime}) by its average value Ï±0subscriptitalic-Ï±0\varrho_{0} in equationÂ (14). A mean field energy spectrum can be constructed in which the massive degeneracy of the original partially filled electron Landau level disappears. One might then hope to treat both the Coulomb interaction and the CS gauge field interactions among the fluctuations (beyond the mean field) by standard many body perturbation techniques (e.g. by the random phase approximation, RPA). Unfortunately, there is no small parameter for a many body perturbation expansion unless Î±ð¼\alpha, the number of CS flux quanta attached to each particle, is small compared to unity. However, a LandauâSilin [20] type Fermi liquid approach can take account of the short range correlations phenomenologically. A number of excellent papers on anyon superconductivity [21] treat CS gauge interactions by standard many body techniques. Halperin and collaborators [11] have treated the half filled Landau level as a liquid of composite Fermions moving in zero effective magnetic field. Their RPAâFermi-liquid approach gives a surprisingly satisfactory account of the properties of that state.

The vector potential associated with fluctuations beyond the mean field is given by Î´âaâ(r)=aâ(r)ââ¨aâ(r)â©ð¿arardelimited-â¨â©ar\delta\bi{a}(\bi{r})=\bi{a}(\bi{r})-\left<\bi{a}(\bi{r})\right>. The perturbation to the mean field Hamiltonian contains both linear and quadratic terms in Î´âaâ(r)ð¿ar\delta\bi{a}(\bi{r}), resulting in both two body â containing Ï±â(r1)âÏ±â(r2)italic-Ï±subscriptr1bold-italic-Ï±subscriptr2\varrho(\bi{r}_{1})\varrho(\bi{r}_{2}) â and three body â containing Ï±â(r1)âÏ±â(r2)âÏ±â(r3)italic-Ï±subscriptr1bold-italic-Ï±subscriptr2bold-italic-Ï±subscriptr3\varrho(\bi{r}_{1})\varrho(\bi{r}_{2})\varrho(\bi{r}_{3}) â interaction terms. The three body interaction terms are usually ignored, though for Î±ð¼\alpha of the order of unity this approximation is of questionable validity.

5 Jainâs Composite Fermion Picture

Jain noted that in the mean field approximation, an effective filling factor Î½âsuperscriptð\nu^{*} of the composite Fermions was related to the electron filling factor Î½ð\nu by the relation

6 Energy Scales and the Electron Pseudopotentials

The mean field composite Fermion picture is remarkably successful in predicting the low energy multiplets in the spectrum of NðN electrons on a Haldane sphere. It was suggested originally that this success resulted from the cancellation of the Coulomb and ChernâSimons gauge interactions among fluctuations beyond the mean field. In figureÂ 2, we show the lowest bands of multiplets for eight non-interacting electrons and for the same number of non-interacting mean field CFâs at 2âS=212ð212S=21.

The energy scale associated with the CS gauge interactions which convert the electron system in frame (a) to the CF system in frame (b) is ââÏcââBproportional-toPlanck-constant-over-2-pisuperscriptsubscriptðððµ\hbar\omega_{c}^{*}\propto B. The energy scale associated with the electron-electron Coulomb interaction is e2/Î»âBproportional-tosuperscriptð2ððµe^{2}/\lambda\propto\sqrt{B}. The Coulomb interaction lifts the degeneracy of the non-interacting electron bands in frame (a). However, for very large value of BðµB the Coulomb energy can be made arbitrarily small compared to the CS energy (as marked with a shaded rectangle in figureÂ 2), i.e. to the separation between the CF Landau levels. The energy separations in the mean field CF model are completely wrong, but the structure of the low lying states (i.e., which angular momentum multiplets form the low lying bands) is very similar to that of the fully interacting electron system and completely different from that of the non-interacting electron system.

6.1 Two Fermion Problem

An intuitive picture of why this occurs can be obtained by considering the two Fermion problem. The relative (REL) motion of a pair of electrons (iâj)ðð(ij) is described by a coordinate ziâj=ziâzj=riâjâeâiâÏiâjsubscriptð§ððsubscriptð§ðsubscriptð§ðsubscriptðððsuperscriptððsubscriptitalic-Ïððz_{ij}=z_{i}-z_{j}=r_{ij}e^{-i\phi_{ij}}, and for the lowest Landau level its wavefunction contains a factor ziâjmsuperscriptsubscriptð§ðððz_{ij}^{m}, where m=1ð1m=1, 3, 5, â¦. If every pair of particles has identical behavior, the many particle wavefunction must contain a similar factor for each pair giving a total factor âi<jziâjmsubscriptproductððsuperscriptsubscriptð§ððð\prod_{i<j}z_{ij}^{m}. As we have seen, the highest power of zisubscriptð§ðz_{i} in this product is mâ(Nâ1)ðð1m(N-1). If mâ(Nâ1)ðð1m(N-1) is equal to NÏâ1=2âSsubscriptðitalic-Ï12ðN_{\phi}-1=2S, the maximum value of the zð§z-component of the single particle angular momentum, the Laughlin Î½=mâ1ðsuperscriptð1\nu=m^{-1} wavefunction results. For electrons, the mðmth cyclotron orbit, whose radius is rmsubscriptððr_{m}, encloses a flux mâÏ0ðsubscriptitalic-Ï0m\phi_{0} (i.e. Ïârm2âB=mâÏ0ðsuperscriptsubscriptðð2ðµðsubscriptitalic-Ï0\pi r_{m}^{2}B=m\phi_{0}). For a Laughlin Î½=mâ1ðsuperscriptð1\nu=m^{-1} state the pair function must have a radius rm=r1âmsubscriptððsubscriptð1ðr_{m}=r_{1}\sqrt{m}. It is apparent that if a flux tube carrying two flux quanta (oriented opposite to the applied magnetic field BðµB) is attached to each electron in the CS transformation of the Î½=1/3ð13\nu=1/3 state, the smallest orbit of radius Ï±m~=1subscriptitalic-Ï±~ð1\varrho_{\tilde{m}=1} has exactly the same size as rm=3subscriptðð3r_{m=3}. Both orbits enclose three flux quanta of the applied field, but the CF orbit also encloses the two oppositely oriented CS flux quanta attached to the electrons to form the CFâs. In the absence of electronâelectron interactions, the energies of these orbits are unchanged, since they still belong to the degenerate single particle states of the lowest Landau level.

In the mean field approximation the CS fluxes are replaced by a spatially uniform magnetic field, leading to an effective field Bâ=B/msuperscriptðµðµðB^{*}=B/m. The orbits for the CF pair states in the mean field approximation are exactly the same as those of the exact CS Hamiltonian. The smallest orbit has radius Ï±m~=1subscriptitalic-Ï±~ð1\varrho_{\tilde{m}=1} equivalent to the electron orbit rm=3subscriptðð3r_{m=3}. However, in the mean field approximation, the energies are changed (because Ïcâ=eâBâ/Î¼âcsuperscriptsubscriptðððsuperscriptðµðð\omega_{c}^{*}=eB^{*}/\mu c replaces Ïcsubscriptðð\omega_{c}). This energy change leads to completely incorrect mean field CF energies, but the mean field CF orbitals give the correct structure to the low lying set of multiplets.

In the presence of a repulsive interaction, the low lying energy states will have the largest possible value of mðm. For a monopole strength 2âS=mâ(Nâ1)2ððð12S=m(N-1), where mðm is an odd integer, every pair can have radius rmsubscriptððr_{m} and avoid the large repulsion associated with r1subscriptð1r_{1}, r3subscriptð3r_{3}, â¦, rmâ2subscriptðð2r_{m-2}. These ideas can be made somewhat more rigorous by using methods of atomic and nuclear physics for studying angular momentum shells of interacting Fermions.

6.2 Two Body Interaction Pseudopotential

As first suggested by Haldane [8], the behavior of the interacting many electron system depends entirely on the behavior of the two body interaction pseudopotential, which is defined as the interaction energy VðV of a pair of electrons as a function of their pair angular momentum. In the spherical geometry, in order to allow for meaningful comparison of the pseudopotentials obtained for different values of 2âS2ð2S (and thus different single electron angular momenta lðl), it is convenient to use the ârelativeâ angular momentum â=2âlâL12â2ðsubscriptð¿12{\cal R}=2l-L_{12} rather than L12subscriptð¿12L_{12} (the length of ^âL12=^âl1+^âl2bold-^absentsubscriptð¿12bold-^absentsubscriptð1bold-^absentsubscriptð2\hat{\bi}{L}_{12}=\hat{\bi}{l}_{1}+\hat{\bi}{l}_{2}). The pair states with a given â=mâð{\cal R}=m (an odd integer) obtained on a sphere for different 2âS2ð2S are equivalent and correspond to the pair state on a plane with the relative (REL) motion described by angular momentum mðm and radius rmsubscriptððr_{m}. The pair state with the smallest allowed orbit (and largest repulsion) has â=1â1{\cal R}=1 on a sphere or m=1ð1m=1 on a plane, and larger ââ{\cal R} and mðm means larger average separation. In the limit of Î»/Râ0âðð0\lambda/R\rightarrow 0 (i.e., either 2âSâââ2ð2S\rightarrow\infty or RâââðR\rightarrow\infty), the pair wavefunctions and energies calculated on a sphere for â=mâð{\cal R}=m converge to the planar ones (Ï0âmsubscriptð0ð\psi_{0m} and its energy).

The pseudopotentials Vâ(â)ðâV({\cal R}) are plotted in figureÂ 3 for a number of values of the monopole strength 2âS2ð2S.

The open circles mark the pseudopotential calculated on a plane (â=mâð{\cal R}=m). At small ââ{\cal R} the pseudopotentials rise very quickly with decreasing ââ{\cal R} (i.e. separation). More importantly, they increase more quickly than linearly as a function of L12â(L12+1)subscriptð¿12subscriptð¿121L_{12}(L_{12}+1). The pseudopotentials with this property form a class of so-called âshort rangeâ repulsive pseudopotentials [12]. If the repulsive interaction has short range, the low energy many body states must, to the extent that it is possible, avoid pair states the smallest values of ââ{\cal R} (or mðm) and the maximum two body repulsion.

The L=0ð¿0L=0 states that appear at 2âl=62ð62l=6 (ââ¥3â3{\cal R}\geq 3), 2âl=102ð102l=10 (ââ¥5â5{\cal R}\geq 5), and 2âl=142ð142l=14 (ââ¥7â7{\cal R}\geq 7) are the only states for these values of 2âl2ð2l that can avoid one, two, or three largest pseudopotential parameters, respectively, and therefore are the non-degenerate (L=0ð¿0L=0) ground states. If only a single multiplet belongs to an angular momentum subspace, its form is completely determined by the requirement that it is an eigenstate of angular momentum with a given eigenvalue Lð¿L. The wavefunction and the type of many body correlations do not depend on the form of the interaction pseudopotential. For interactions that do not have short range, the state that avoids the largest two body repulsion (e.g. the L=0ð¿0L=0 multiplet at 2âl=62ð62l=6) might not have the lowest total three body interaction energy and be the ground state. If more than one multiplet belongs to a given angular momentum eigenvalue (e.g., two multiplets occur at L=3ð¿3L=3 for 2âl=82ð82l=8), the interparticle interaction must be diagonalized in this subspace (two-dimensional for 2âl=82ð82l=8 and L=3ð¿3L=3). Whether the lowest energy eigenstate in this subspace has Laughlin type correlations, i.e. avoids as much as possible largest two body repulsion, depends critically on the short range of the interaction pseudopotential. For the Coulomb interaction, we find that the Laughlin correlations occur and, whenever possible, the CFP of the lowest lying multiplets virtually vanishes (it would vanish exactly for an âidealâ short range pseudopotential which increases infinitely quickly with decreasing ââ{\cal R}). For example, for the lower energy eigenstate at L=3ð¿3L=3 and 2âl=82ð82l=8, the CFP for â=1â1{\cal R}=1 is less than 10â3superscript10310^{-3}. At 2âS=142ð142S=14 for L=6ð¿6L=6 there are three allowed multiplets. The diagonalization of the Coulomb interaction gives the lowest state that avoids â=1â1{\cal R}=1 (CFP â¼10â7similar-toabsentsuperscript107\sim 10^{-7}) and â=3â3{\cal R}=3 (CFP <10â2absentsuperscript102<10^{-2}), and the next lowest state that avoids â=1â1{\cal R}=1 (CFP <10â5absentsuperscript105<10^{-5}) but orthogonality to the lowest state requires that it has significant parentage from â=3â3{\cal R}=3 (CFP â0.34absent0.34\approx 0.34).

One can see that the set of angular momentum multiplets Lð¿L that can be constructed at a given value of 2âl2ð2l without parentage from pair states with â=1â1{\cal R}=1 is identical to the set of all allowed multiplets Lð¿L at 2âlâ=2âlâ42superscriptð2ð42l^{*}=2l-4. For a short range repulsion (e.g. the Coulomb repulsion in the lowest Landau level), these multiplets will be (to a good approximation) the lowest energy eigenstates (the appropriate CFP for the actual eigenstates will be very small although not necessarily zero). More generally, in the lowest Landau level (remember that l=Sððl=S), the set of multiplets Lð¿L that can be constructed at given 2âS2ð2S without parentage from ââ¤2âpâ1â2ð1{\cal R}\leq 2p-1 (i.e. with ââ¥2âp+1â2ð1{\cal R}\geq 2p+1 for all pairs; p=1ð1p=1, 2, â¦) is identical to the set of all allowed multiplets Lð¿L at 2âSâ=2âSâ2âpâ(Nâ1)2superscriptð2ð2ðð12S^{*}=2S-2p(N-1). The multiplets Lð¿L forming the lowest Coulomb energy band at a given 2âS2ð2S are all multiplets allowed at 2âSâ2superscriptð2S^{*}. But 2âSâ=2âSâ2âpâ(Nâ1)2superscriptð2ð2ðð12S^{*}=2S-2p(N-1) is just the effective magnetic monopole strength in the mean field CF picture! Thus the CF picture with 2âp2ð2p attached flux quanta simply picks the subset of angular momentum multiplets which have no parentage from pair states with ââ¤2âpâ1â2ð1{\cal R}\leq 2p-1, and neglects the long range part of the pseudopotential, Vâ(â)ðâV({\cal R}) for ââ¥2âp+1â2ð1{\cal R}\geq 2p+1.

Because the expectation value of âi<jL^iâj2subscriptððsuperscriptsubscript^ð¿ðð2\sum_{i<j}\hat{L}_{ij}^{2} in a many body state of angular momentum Lð¿L increases as Lâ(L+1)ð¿ð¿1L(L+1), a strict Hundâs rule holds for harmonic pseudopotentials: For VHsubscriptðð»V_{H} that increases as a function of L12subscriptð¿12L_{12}, the highest energy state is always at the maximum possible value of Lð¿L equal to LMAX=NâlâNâ(Nâ1)/2superscriptð¿MAXðððð12L^{\rm MAX}=Nl-N(N-1)/2, and the lowest energy state is at the minimum allowed value of Lð¿L equal to LMINsuperscriptð¿MINL^{\rm MIN}. If VHsubscriptðð»V_{H} decreases as a function of L12subscriptð¿12L_{12}, the opposite occurs: the lowest energy state is at LMAXsuperscriptð¿MAXL^{\rm MAX}, and the highest energy state is at LMINsuperscriptð¿MINL^{\rm MIN} (this is a standard Hundâs rule of atomic physics).

Neither of these Hundâs rules may remain true in the presence of a large anharmonic term ÎâVÎð\Delta V. For example, if the number of multiplets NLsubscriptðð¿N_{L} at a value slightly larger than LMINsuperscriptð¿MINL^{\rm MIN} is very large compared to NLMINsubscriptðsuperscriptð¿MINN_{L^{\rm MIN}}, the strong level repulsion due to ÎâVÎð\Delta V within this Lð¿L subspace can overcome the difference in the expectation values of VHsubscriptðð»V_{H}, and the lowest eigenvalue of VðV at Lð¿L can be lower than that at LMINsuperscriptð¿MINL^{\rm MIN}. However, only very few multiplets occur at large values of Lð¿L: NLMAX=1subscriptðsuperscriptð¿MAX1N_{L^{\rm MAX}}=1 (for M=L=LMAXðð¿superscriptð¿MAXM=L=L^{\rm MAX}, the only state is |l,lâ1,â¦,lâN+1â©ketðð1â¦ðð1\left|l,l-1,\dots,l-N+1\right>), NLMAXâ1=0subscriptðsuperscriptð¿MAX10N_{L^{\rm MAX}-1}=0, NLMAXâ2â¤1subscriptðsuperscriptð¿MAX21N_{L^{\rm MAX}-2}\leq 1, NLMAXâ3â¤1subscriptðsuperscriptð¿MAX31N_{L^{\rm MAX}-3}\leq 1, etc. As a result, breaking of the Hundâs rule that refers to the behavior of energy at large Lð¿L requires stronger anharmonicity than at small Lð¿L. For the Coulomb pseudopotential in the lowest Landau level we always find that the highest energy indeed occurs at LMAXsuperscriptð¿MAXL^{\rm MAX}. However, the ability to avoid parentage from pair states having large Liâjsubscriptð¿ððL_{ij} often favors many body states at small L>LMINð¿superscriptð¿MINL>L^{\rm MIN} with large NLsubscriptðð¿N_{L}, as prescribed by the CF picture.

The anharmonicity of the Coulomb pseudopotential in the lowest Landau level (which increases with increasing L12subscriptð¿12L_{12}) is critical for the behavior of the FQH systems. We have found that the condition for the occurrence of subbands separated by gaps in the energy spectrum, and, in particular, for the occurrence of non-degenerate incompressible fluid ground states at specific values of the filling factor, is that the anharmonic term ÎâVâ(L12)Îðsubscriptð¿12\Delta V(L_{12}) is positive and increases with increasing L12subscriptð¿12L_{12}. In other words, the total pseudopotential Vâ(L12)ðsubscriptð¿12V(L_{12}) must increase more quickly than linearly as a function of L12â(L12+1)subscriptð¿12subscriptð¿121L_{12}(L_{12}+1).

6.6 Comparison with Atomic Shells: Hundâs Rule

Our conjectures (verified by the numerical experiments) are based on the behavior of systems of interacting Fermions partially filling a shell of degenerate single particle states of angular momentum lðl. This is a central problem in atomic physics and in nuclear shell model studies of energy spectra. It is interesting to compare the behavior of the spherical harmonics of atomic physics with that of the monopole harmonics considered here. For monopole harmonics l=S+nðððl=S+n, where SðS is half of the monopole strength (and can be integral or half integral) and nðn is a non-negative integer. For the lowest angular momentum shell l=Sððl=S. For spherical harmonics S=0ð0S=0 and l=nððl=n. If in each case electrons are confined to a 2D spherical surface of radius RðR, one can evaluate the pair interaction energy VðV as a function of the pair angular momentum L12subscriptð¿12L_{12}. The resulting pseudopotentials, Vâ(â)ðâV({\cal R}) for the FQH system in the lowest Landau level, and Vâ(L12)ðsubscriptð¿12V(L_{12}) for atomic shells in a zero magnetic field, are shown in figureÂ 5 for a few small values of lðl.

In obtaining these results we have restricted ourselves to spin-polarized shells, so only orbital angular momentum is considered. It is clear that in the case of spherical harmonics the largest pseudopotential coefficient occurs for the lowest pair angular momentum, exactly the opposite of what occurs for monopole harmonics. As a consequence of equationÂ (19), which relates the total angular momentum Lð¿L to the average pair angular momentum L12subscriptð¿12L_{12}, the standard atomic Hundâs rule predicts that the energy of a few electron system in an atomic shell will, on the average, decrease as a function of total angular momentum, which is opposite to the behavior of energy of electrons in the lowest Landau level. The difference between the energy spectra of electrons interacting through atomic and FQH pseudopotentials of figureÂ 5 is demonstrated in figureÂ 6, where we plot the result for four electrons in shells of angular momentum l=3ð3l=3 and 5.

The solid circles correspond to monopole harmonics and the open ones to spherical harmonics. Note that at LMAXsuperscriptð¿MAXL^{\rm MAX} the former give the highest energy and the latter the lowest. Due to anharmonicity of the pseudopotentials, the behavior of energy at low Lð¿L does not always follow a simple Hundâs rule for either FQH or atomic system. The FQH ground state for l=3ð3l=3 occurs at L=0ð¿0L=0 (this is the Î½=2/3ð23\nu=2/3 incompressible state). However, for l=5ð5l=5, the lowest of the three states at L=2ð¿2L=2 has lower energy than the only state L=0ð¿0L=0. This ground state at L=2ð¿2L=2 contains one quasihole in the Laughlin Î½=1/3ð13\nu=1/3 state and it is the only four electron state at this filling in which electrons can avoid parentage from the â=1â1{\cal R}=1 pair state. Exactly opposite happens for the atomic system at l=5ð5l=5, where the anharmonicity is able to push the highest of the three L=2ð¿2L=2 states above the high energy state at L=0ð¿0L=0.

6.7 Higher Landau Levels

Thus far we have considered only the lowest angular momentum shell (lowest Landau level) with l=Sððl=S The interaction of a pair of electrons in the nðnth excited shell of angular momentum l=S+nðððl=S+n can easily be evaluated to obtain the pseudopotentials Vâ(L12)ðsubscriptð¿12V(L_{12}) shown in figureÂ 7.

Here we compare Vnâ(L12)subscriptððsubscriptð¿12V_{n}(L_{12}) as a function of L12â(L12+1)subscriptð¿12subscriptð¿121L_{12}(L_{12}+1) for n=0ð0n=0, 1, and 2. It can readily be observed that Vn=0subscriptðð0V_{n=0} increases more quickly than L12â(L12+1)subscriptð¿12subscriptð¿121L_{12}(L_{12}+1) in entire range of L12subscriptð¿12L_{12}, while Vn=1subscriptðð1V_{n=1} and Vn=2subscriptðð2V_{n=2} do so only up to certain value of L12subscriptð¿12L_{12} (i.e., above certain value of â=2âlâL12â2ðsubscriptð¿12{\cal R}=2l-L_{12}) For n=1ð1n=1, the Vn=1subscriptðð1V_{n=1} has short range for ââ¥3â3{\cal R}\geq 3 but is essentially linear in L12â(L12+1)subscriptð¿12subscriptð¿121L_{12}(L_{12}+1) from â=1â1{\cal R}=1 to 5. For n=2ð2n=2, the Vn=2subscriptðð2V_{n=2} has short range for ââ¥5â5{\cal R}\geq 5 but is sublinear in L12â(L12+1)subscriptð¿12subscriptð¿121L_{12}(L_{12}+1) from â=1â1{\cal R}=1 to 7. More generally, we find that the pseudopotential in the nðnth excited shell (Landau level) has short range for ââ¥2ân+1â2ð1{\cal R}\geq 2n+1.

Because the conclusions of the CF picture depend so critically on the short range of the pseudopotential, they are not expected to be valid for all fractional fillings of higher Landau levels. For example, the ground state at Î½=2+1/3=7/3ð21373\nu=2+1/3=7/3 does not have Laughlin type correlations (i.e. electrons in the n=1ð1n=1 Landau level do not avoid parentage from â=1â1{\cal R}=1) even if it is non-degenerate (L=0ð¿0L=0) and incompressible (as found experimentally [22]).

7 Fermi Liquid Model of Composite Fermions

The numerical results of the type shown in figureÂ 1 have been understood in a very simple way using Jainâs composite Fermion picture. The energy spectra of states containing more than one CF quasiparticle can be described in the following phenomenological Fermi liquid picture. The creation of an elementary excitation, QE or QH, in a Laughlin incompressible ground state requires a finite energy, ÎµQEsubscriptðQE\varepsilon_{\rm QE} or ÎµQHsubscriptðQH\varepsilon_{\rm QH}, respectively. In a state containing more than one Laughlin quasiparticle, QEâs and/or QHâs interact with one another through appropriate QEâQE, QHâQH, and QEâQH pseudopotentials.

There can be finite size effects here, because the QP states occur at different values of 2âS2ð2S than the ground state, but using the correct magnetic length Î»=R/Sððð\lambda=R/\sqrt{S} (RðR is the radius of the sphere) in the unit of energy e2/Î»superscriptð2ðe^{2}/\lambda at each value of 2âS2ð2S, and extrapolating the results as a function of Nâ1superscriptð1N^{-1} to an infinite system should give reliable estimates of ÎµQEsubscriptðQE\varepsilon_{\rm QE} and ÎµQHsubscriptðQH\varepsilon_{\rm QH} for a macroscopic system.

In figureÂ 8 we plot the QEâQE and QHâQH pseudopotentials for Laughlin Î½=1/3ð13\nu=1/3 and 1/5 states.

As we have seen for two electrons (see figureÂ 3), the angular momentum L12subscriptð¿12L_{12} of a pair of identical Fermions in an angular momentum shell (or a Landau level) is quantized, and the convenient quantum number to label the pair states is â=2âlQPâL12â2subscriptðQPsubscriptð¿12{\cal R}=2l_{\rm QP}-L_{12} (on a sphere) or relative (REL) angular momentum mðm (on a plane). As for a conduction electron and a valence hole pair in a semiconductor (an exciton), the motion of a QEâQH pair which does not carry a net electric charge is not quantized in a magnetic field. 8 Composite Fermion Hierarchy

The sequence of LaughlinâJain states with filling factor Î½ð\nu given by Î½=Î½ââ(1+2âpâÎ½â)â1ðsuperscriptðsuperscript12ðsuperscriptð1\nu=\nu^{*}(1+2p\nu^{*})^{-1} where p=1ð1p=1, 2, â¦, and the CF filling factor Î½âsuperscriptð\nu^{*} is any non-zero integer, is the most prominent set of condensed states observed experimentally. However, this sequence (together with the conjugate âholeâ states, Î½â1âÎ½âð1ð\nu\rightarrow 1-\nu) does not contain all odd denominator fractions the way the Haldane hierarchy scheme does. The question arises quite naturally of how to treat the CF values of Î½âsuperscriptð\nu^{*} which are not integers. The answer leads to the CF approach to the hierarchy of incompressible quantum fluid ground states [13].

Consider a state of N0subscriptð0N_{0} electrons at a monopole strength 2âS02subscriptð02S_{0} with a filling factor Î½0subscriptð0\nu_{0}. If Î½1âsuperscriptsubscriptð1\nu_{1}^{*} is an integer, we obtain a daughter states in the hierarchy. If it is not, we write Î½1â=n2+Î½2superscriptsubscriptð1subscriptð2subscriptð2\nu_{1}^{*}=n_{2}+\nu_{2}, where Î½2subscriptð2\nu_{2} represents the partial filling of the new QP shell, and repeat the mean field CF procedure. This leads to the set of equations:

Î½lâ1=2âpl+(nl+1+Î½l+1)â1,superscriptsubscriptðð12subscriptððsuperscriptsubscriptðð1subscriptðð11\nu_{l}^{-1}=2p_{l}+(n_{l+1}+\nu_{l+1})^{-1}, (26)

If the mean field CF picture worked on all levels of hierarchy, the twelve electron system at 2âS=302ð302S=30 should have an incompressible L=0ð¿0L=0 ground state corresponding to the filling factor Î½=6/17ð617\nu=6/17. Though the CF hierarchy picture seems to work in some cases, there are others where it is clearly in complete disagreement with numerical results. For example, a CF transformation with 2âp0=22subscriptð022p_{0}=2 applied to an N0=8subscriptð08N_{0}=8 electron system at 2âS0=182subscriptð0182S_{0}=18 gives 2âS0â=18â2â(8â1)=42superscriptsubscriptð01828142S_{0}^{*}=18-2(8-1)=4, n1=1subscriptð11n_{1}=1, and N1=3subscriptð13N_{1}=3 QEâs left in the shell with l1=3subscriptð13l_{1}=3. From equationÂ (26) we get Î½1=1/3subscriptð113\nu_{1}=1/3 and Î½0=4/11subscriptð0411\nu_{0}=4/11. The reason why the CF hierarchy picture does not always work is not difficult to understand. The electron (Coulomb) pseudopotential in the lowest Landau level Veâ(â)subscriptððâV_{e}({\cal R}) satisfies the âshort rangeâ criterion (i.e. it increases more quickly with decreasing ââ{\cal R} than the harmonic pseudopotential VHsubscriptðð»V_{H}) in the entire range of ââ{\cal R}, which is the reason for the incompressibility of the principal Laughlin Î½=(2âp+1)â1ðsuperscript2ð11\nu=(2p+1)^{-1} states. However, this does not generally hold for the QP pseudopotentials on higher levels of the hierarchy. In figureÂ 8 we plotted VQEâQEâ(â)subscriptðQEQEâV_{\rm QE-QE}({\cal R}) and VQHâQHâ(â)subscriptðQHQHâV_{\rm QH-QH}({\cal R}) for the Î½=1/3ð13\nu=1/3 and Î½=1/5ð15\nu=1/5 Laughlin states of six to eleven electrons. Clearly, the QE and QH pseudopotentials are quite different and neither one decreases monotonically with increasing ââ{\cal R}. On the other hand, the corresponding pseudopotentials in Î½=1/3ð13\nu=1/3 and 1/5 states look similar, only the energy scale is different. The convergence of energies at small ââ{\cal R} obtained for larger NðN suggests that the maxima at â=3â3{\cal R}=3 for QEâs and at â=1â1{\cal R}=1 and 5 for QHâs, as well as the minima at â=1â1{\cal R}=1 and 5 for QEâs and at â=3â3{\cal R}=3 and 7 for QHâs, persist in the limit of large NðN (i.e. for an infinite system on a plane). Consequently, the only incompressible daughter states of Laughlin Î½=1/3ð13\nu=1/3 and 1/5 states are those with Î½QE=1subscriptðQE1\nu_{\rm QE}=1 or Î½QH=1/3subscriptðQH13\nu_{\rm QH}=1/3 and (maybe) Î½QE=1/5subscriptðQE15\nu_{\rm QE}=1/5 and Î½QH=1/7subscriptðQH17\nu_{\rm QH}=1/7. It is clear that no incompressible daughter states of the parent Laughlin Î½=1/3ð13\nu=1/3 state will form at e.g. Î½=4/11ð411\nu=4/11 (Î½QE=1/3subscriptðQE13\nu_{\rm QE}=1/3) or 4/13 (Î½QH=1/5subscriptðQH15\nu_{\rm QH}=1/5), but that they will form (at least, in finite systems [24]) at Î½=6/17ð617\nu=6/17 (Î½QE=1/5subscriptðQE15\nu_{\rm QE}=1/5) or 4/13 (Î½QH=1/7subscriptðQH17\nu_{\rm QH}=1/7).

From the CF hierarchy scheme we find the JainâLaughlin states when the CS transformation is applied directly to electrons (or to holes in a more than half-filled level). These states occur at integral values of Î½âsuperscriptð\nu^{*}, the effective CF filling factor, and correspond to completely filling a QP shell. For example, the Î½=2/5ð25\nu=2/5 state occurs when Î½â=2superscriptð2\nu^{*}=2, and the CFâs in the first excited shell (which are Laughlin QEâs of the Î½=1/3ð13\nu=1/3 state) have Î½QP=1subscriptðQP1\nu_{\rm QP}=1. The angular momenta of the two lowest CF shells are l0â=|Sâ|superscriptsubscriptð0superscriptðl_{0}^{*}=|S^{*}| and l1â=|Sâ|+1superscriptsubscriptð1superscriptð1l_{1}^{*}=|S^{*}|+1, so they contain 2âl0â+12superscriptsubscriptð012l_{0}^{*}+1 and 2âl1â+12superscriptsubscriptð112l_{1}^{*}+1 states, respectively. Since Î½QP=1subscriptðQP1\nu_{\rm QP}=1, there are NQP=2âl1â+1subscriptðQP2superscriptsubscriptð11N_{\rm QP}=2l_{1}^{*}+1 CF quasiparticles. The total number of states filled by the NðN Fermions is (2âl0â+1)+(2âl1â+1)=2âNQPâ22superscriptsubscriptð012superscriptsubscriptð112subscriptðQP2(2l_{0}^{*}+1)+(2l_{1}^{*}+1)=2N_{\rm QP}-2, giving N=2âNQPâ2ð2subscriptðQP2N=2N_{\rm QP}-2. For an infinite system this is just Haldaneâs relation between the number of quasiparticles and the number of electrons, N=2âqâNQPð2ðsubscriptðQPN=2qN_{\rm QP}, for the integer q=1ð1q=1. This demonstrates that integrally filled CF shells correspond to Î½QP=1subscriptðQP1\nu_{\rm QP}=1, a completely filled shell of Laughlin QPâs. Adding new Fermions to a system with Î½QP=1subscriptðQP1\nu_{\rm QP}=1 requires creating a new type of QPâs, and the counting of available QP states turns out to be exactly the same in the CF hierarchy and Haldaneâs Boson hierarchy picrures. Integral CF filling (i.e., Î½QP=1subscriptðQP1\nu_{\rm QP}=1) gives a valid mean field picture independent of QPâQP interactions provided that the gap for creating new QPâs is positive. When Î½âsuperscriptð\nu^{*} is non-integral, the mean field picture is valid only at values of Lð¿L for which the âshort rangeâ requirement on the pseudopotential VQPâQPâ(L)subscriptðQPQPð¿V_{\rm QP-QP}(L) is satisfied. The form of the QPâQP interactions obtained from our numerical calculations makes it clear that the mean field approximation is not valid at certain quasiparticle fillings (e.g. for Î½QP=1/3subscriptðQP13\nu_{\rm QP}=1/3 filling of the quasielectron levels of the electron Î½=1/3ð13\nu=1/3 state).

9 Systems Containing Electrons and Valence Band Holes

There has been a great deal of interest in photoluminescence (PL) of 2D systems in high magnetic fields. An important ingredient in understanding PL is the negatively charged exciton (XâsuperscriptðX^{-}). The XâsuperscriptðX^{-} consists of two electrons bound to a valence band hole. If the total spin of the pair of electrons, Jesubscriptð½ðJ_{e}, is zero, the XâsuperscriptðX^{-} is said to be a singlet (Xsâsubscriptsuperscriptðð X^{-}_{s}); if Je=1subscriptð½ð1J_{e}=1 the XâsuperscriptðX^{-} is called a triplet (Xtâsubscriptsuperscriptðð¡X^{-}_{t}). Only the Xsâsubscriptsuperscriptðð X^{-}_{s} is bound in the absence of a magnetic field, but in infinite magnetic field (so that only a single Landau level is relevant) only the Xtâsubscriptsuperscriptðð¡X^{-}_{t} is bound in a 2D system. It often occurs that the photoexcited hole is separated from the plane of the electron system by a small distance (this can happen, e.g., in wide GaAs quantum wells when the electron gas is confined to one GaAs/AlGaAs interface by remote ionized donors, and the photoexcited holes reside close to the other GaAs/AlGaAs interface). Several remarkable effects associated with electronâhole systems and charged excitons can be understood using the composite Fermion picture.

9.1 Charged Exciton and the Hidden Symmetry in the Lowest Landau Level

First let us consider the idealized 2D system at so large a magnetic field that only the lowest electron and hole Landau levels need be considered. The energy spectrum for a two-electronâone-hole system at 2âS=202ð202S=20 is shown in figureÂ 12.

The triplet XâsuperscriptðX^{-} with angular momentum lXâ=Sâ1subscriptðsuperscriptðð1l_{X^{-}}=S-1 is the only bound state, with binding energy â¼0.05âe2/Î»similar-toabsent0.05superscriptð2ð\sim 0.05e^{2}/\lambda. A pair of (unbound) singlet and triplet states occur at the energy equal exactly to the exciton energy EXsubscriptð¸ðE_{X}. In these so-called âmultiplicativeâ states a neutral exciton XðX in its ground state is decoupled from the second electron. Addition of exciton and electron angular momenta LX=0subscriptð¿ð0L_{X}=0 and le=Ssubscriptðððl_{e}=S gives a state of total angular momentum L=Sð¿ðL=S, and addition of two electron spins of 1/2121/2 gives both Je=0subscriptð½ð0J_{e}=0 and 1 spin configurations.

The occurrence of unbound states at E=EXð¸subscriptð¸ðE=E_{X} and L=Sð¿ðL=S is a manifestation of the following âhidden symmetry:â Because of the exact overlap of electron and hole orbitals in the lowest Landau level (scaled with the same magnetic length Î»ð\lambda), and thus independence of the strength of interaction of the type of particles involved, the commutator of an operator dXâ superscriptsubscriptððâ d_{X}^{\dagger} that creates an exciton in its LX=0subscriptð¿ð0L_{X}=0 ground state (on a sphere, dXâ =âm(â1)mâcmâ âhmâ superscriptsubscriptððâ subscriptðsuperscript1ðsuperscriptsubscriptððâ superscriptsubscriptâðâ d_{X}^{\dagger}=\sum_{m}(-1)^{m}c_{m}^{\dagger}h_{m}^{\dagger}, where cmâ superscriptsubscriptððâ c_{m}^{\dagger} and hmâ superscriptsubscriptâðâ h_{m}^{\dagger} are electron and hole creation operators), with the interaction Hamiltonian Hð»H is [H,dXâ ]=EXâdXâ ð»superscriptsubscriptððâ subscriptð¸ðsuperscriptsubscriptððâ [H,d_{X}^{\dagger}]=E_{X}d_{X}^{\dagger}. As a result, if Î¨Î¨\Psi is an eigenstate of NesubscriptððN_{e} electrons and NhsubscriptðâN_{h} holes with an eigenenergy Eð¸E and angular momentum quantum numbers Lð¿L and MðM, then the multiplicative state dXâ âÎ¨superscriptsubscriptððâ Î¨d_{X}^{\dagger}\Psi of Ne+1subscriptðð1N_{e}+1 electrons and Nh+1subscriptðâ1N_{h}+1 holes is also an eigenstate with energy E+EXð¸subscriptð¸ðE+E_{X} and the same Lð¿L and MðM. A good quantum number conserved due to the âhidden symmetryâ is the number of decoupled excitons, NXsubscriptððN_{X}. In particular, the ground state for Ne=Nh=NsubscriptððsubscriptðâðN_{e}=N_{h}=N is the totally multiplicative state (dXâ )Nâ|vacâ©superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptððâ ðketvac(d_{X}^{\dagger})^{N}\left|{\rm vac}\right> with NX=NsubscriptðððN_{X}=N; for an infinite system this ground state can be viewed as a Bose condensate of non-interacting excitons. It can be readily found that the application of the PL operator that annihilates an optically active exciton (dXsubscriptððd_{X}) reduces its NXsubscriptððN_{X} by one, and therefore that only the multiplicative electronâhole states with NX>0subscriptðð0N_{X}>0 are optically active (have non-vanishing PL intensity). In figureÂ 12, the two multiplicative states at E=EXð¸subscriptð¸ðE=E_{X} and L=Sð¿ðL=S have NX=1subscriptðð1N_{X}=1, and all others have NX=0subscriptðð0N_{X}=0.

It is essential to realize that two independent symmetries forbid the recombination of a triplet XâsuperscriptðX^{-} ground state in figureÂ 12:

  • â¢

    Due to the 2D translational/rotational space invariance, the PL operator dXsubscriptððd_{X} conserves two angular momentum quantum numbers. On a sphere, these are is Lð¿L and MðM, and the resulting optical selection rule allows only a state with L=Sð¿ðL=S to decay by eðeâhâh recombination. This (geometrical) symmetry can be broken by collisions, but persists in systems with a finite quantum well width, finite electron and hole layer separation, or Landau level mixing.

  • â¢

    Due to the equal strength of eðeâeðe, hâhâhâh, and eðeâhâh interactions, NXsubscriptððN_{X} is a good quantum number. Since NXsubscriptððN_{X} is decreased in a PL process, only the multiplicative (NX>0subscriptðð0N_{X}>0) states are radiative. This (dynamical) symmetry is not broken by collisions, and requires breaking electronâhole orbital symmetry.

Since a number of independent factors are needed to allow for the recombination of a triplet XâsuperscriptðX^{-}, this complex (in narrow and symmetric quantum wells and in high magnetic fields) is expected to be a well defined long-lived quasiparticle. The correlations, optical properties, etc. are expressed more easily in terms of this quasiparticle than in terms of individual electrons and holes. The finite angular momentum of an XâsuperscriptðX^{-} in spherical geometry (decoupling of the CM excitations from the REL motion on a plane) can be viewed as the formation of a degenerate Landau level of this (charged) quasiparticle. As will be shown later, the interaction of XâsuperscriptðX^{-} quasiparticles with one another and with electrons can be described using the ideas familiar in the context of FQH systems (Laughlin correlations, composite Fermions, parentage, etc.).

The identification of pair states AâBð´ðµAB in figureÂ 13 (as marked with lines) was possible by comparing the displayed 4âe4ð4eâ2âh2â2h spectrum with the pseudopotentials of point charge particles with appropriate angular momenta lAsubscriptðð´l_{A} and lBsubscriptððµl_{B} and binding energies ÎµAsubscriptðð´\varepsilon_{A} and ÎµBsubscriptððµ\varepsilon_{B} [17]. The appropriate values of angular momenta lAsubscriptðð´l_{A} and lBsubscriptððµl_{B}, and of the binding energies ÎµAsubscriptðð´\varepsilon_{A} and ÎµBsubscriptððµ\varepsilon_{B} are obtained by diagonalizing smaller systems (e.g. the 2âe2ð2eâ1âh1â1h system in figureÂ 12 for an XâsuperscriptðX^{-}), and the point charge pseudopotentials are used to approximate the AâBð´ðµAB interaction. This implies that, due to different energy scales, the internal dynamics of charged excitons is weakly coupled to their scattering off one another or off electrons, and allows for the interpretation of an electronâhole system in terms of well defined charged excitonic quasiparticles interacting with one another and with excess electrons through Coulomb like forces. Slight difference between the actual pseudopotentials in figureÂ 13 and the pseudopotentials of point charge particles comes from the larger size of charged excitons and their (nearly frozen) internal degrees of freedom. The latter can be accounted for phenomenologically by attributing each type of composite particles a finite electric polarizability to describe their induced electric dipole moment in the presence of an electric field of other charged particles. Due to an increased charge isotropy, the polarization effects are expected to be greatly reduced in larger systems, and disappear completely in the fluid type states discussed in the following paragraphs.

9.3 Generalized Composite Fermion Picture for Charged Excitons

Suppose we have a system of different (distinguishable) charged Fermions (Að´A, BðµB, â¦). They can be distinguished either because they are different species (e.g., electrons and charged excitons) or because they are confined to different, spatially separated layers. If all particles in such system repel one another through short range pseudopotentials (as defined for the electron FQH systems), one can think of many body states with Laughlin-type correlations [6, 7] given by a generalized (compare equationÂ (5)) LaughlinâJastrow factor

where zi(A)superscriptsubscriptð§ðð´z_{i}^{(A)} is the complex coordinate for the position of the iðith Fermion of type Að´A, and the product is over all pairs. The restrictions on the integers mAâBsubscriptðð´ðµm_{AB} are that mAâAsubscriptðð´ð´m_{AA} must be odd, mBâA=mAâBsubscriptððµð´subscriptðð´ðµm_{BA}=m_{AB}, and mAâBsubscriptðð´ðµm_{AB} must not be smaller than certain minimum values âAâBMINsuperscriptsubscriptâð´ðµMIN{\cal R}_{AB}^{\rm MIN} to avoid the infinite hard cores for all pairs. This intuitive property of the Laughlin fluid states will be very useful in the discussion of collision assisted XâsuperscriptðX^{-} recombination.

A generalized CF picture can be constructed for a system with Laughlin correlations. Although the hidden symmetry is only approximate at d>0ð0d>0, these bands can be easily identified at d=0.5âÎ»ð0.5ðd=0.5\lambda in frame (b).

At an intermediate separation of d=1.75âÎ»ð1.75ðd=1.75\lambda in frame (c), neither description used for d<Î»ððd<\lambda or dâ«Î»much-greater-thanððd\gg\lambda is valid, and it seems that a low energy band occurs at L=0ð¿0L=0, 1, 2, 32superscript323^{2}, 4, 5, and 6. Most likely, the XâsuperscriptðX^{-} unbinds but the hole is still able to bind one electron, forming an exciton with a significant electric dipole moment. This dipole moment results in repulsion between the exciton the remaining six electrons, so that the correlations are quite different than at d=0ð0d=0, where the exciton decouples.

The PL spectrum can be evaluated from the eigenfunctions obtained in the numerical diagonalization of finite systems. For dâ«0much-greater-thanð0d\gg 0, between one and three peaks are observed in the PL spectrum [23]. Their separations are related to the Laughlin gap (for creation of a QEâQH pair) and to the energy of interaction between the valence band hole and the electron system.

9.5 Charged Excitons at a Finite Magnetic Field

One final point is worth mentioning. The numerical calculations described so far were performed for an idealized model in which electrons and holes were confined to infinitely thin 2âD2ð·2D layers, and only the lowest Landau level was considered. For realistic systems, effects due to spin, finite width of the quantum well, and Landau level mixing are very important. The energy spectra of the simple 2âe2ð2eâ1âh1â1h system calculated at 2âS=202ð202S=20 for parameters appropriate to a 11.5Â nm GaAs/AlGaAs quantum well are shown in figureÂ 16.

Two frames correspond to the magnetic field of B=13ðµ13B=13Â T and 68Â T. We used five electron and hole Landau levels (nâ¤4ð4n\leq 4) in the calculation, with the realistic magnetic field dependence of the hole cyclotron mass and the appropriate Zeeman splittings. The interaction matrix elements included finite (and different) effective widths of electron and hole quasi-2D layers.

There are a number of bound XâsuperscriptðX^{-} states in both frames, in contrast to only one singlet bound state at B=0ðµ0B=0 or only one triplet bound state predicted for an idealized system at infinite BðµB. Three of these bound states are of particular importance. The Xsâsubscriptsuperscriptðð X^{-}_{s} and Xtâbâsubscriptsuperscriptðð¡ðX^{-}_{tb} (bðb for âbrightâ), the lowest singlet and triplet states at L=Sð¿ðL=S, are the only well bound radiative states, while Xtâdâsubscriptsuperscriptðð¡ðX^{-}_{td} (dðd for âdarkâ) has by far the lowest energy of all non-radiative (Lâ Sð¿ðL\neq S) states. The dark triplet state Xtâdâsubscriptsuperscriptðð¡ðX^{-}_{td} is the state discussed in the preceding sections; it is the only bound state in the lowest Landau level, but unbinds at low magnetic fields. The bright singlet state Xsâsubscriptsuperscriptðð X^{-}_{s} is the only bound state at B=0ðµ0B=0, but unbinds at very high fields due to the hidden symmetry. These states cross at Bâ30ðµ30B\approx 30Â T, as predicted in an earlier calculation [25]. The bright triplet state Xtâbâsubscriptsuperscriptðð¡ðX^{-}_{tb} has been discovered very recently [26]. It occurs only at intermediate fields and does not cross neither Xsâsubscriptsuperscriptðð X^{-}_{s} or Xtâdâsubscriptsuperscriptðð¡ðX^{-}_{td}. It has larger PL intensity than the Xsâsubscriptsuperscriptðð X^{-}_{s} state.

Although an isolated Xtâdâsubscriptsuperscriptðð¡ðX^{-}_{td} is non-radiative because of the angular momentum selection rule, its collisions with other XâsuperscriptðX^{-}âs or with electrons (which break the translational symmetry) could be expected to allow for Xtâdâsubscriptsuperscriptðð¡ðX^{-}_{td} recombination. However, the Laughlin correlations limit high energy collisions at low filling density (Î½â¼1/5similar-toð15\nu\sim 1/5 or less) and the PL intensity of a dark Xtâdâsubscriptsuperscriptðð¡ðX^{-}_{td} remains very low also in a presence of other particles [26]. In consequence, the Xtâdâsubscriptsuperscriptðð¡ðX^{-}_{td} is not seen in PL, and there is no contradiction between experiment [27], which sees recombination of a triplet state at the energy above the singlet state up to 50Â T, and theory [25], which predicts that the lowest triplet state crosses the singlet at roughly 30Â T.

10 Summary

We have introduced the Jain CF mean field picture and shown how the low lying states can be understood by simple addition of angular momentum. The mean field CF picture gives the correct spectral structure not because of some cancellation between ChernâSimons and Coulomb interactions beyond the mean field, but because it selects a low angular momentum subset of the allowed multiplets that avoids the largest pair repulsion. The Laughlin correlations, which describe incompressible quantum fluid states, depend critically on the electron pseudopotential being of âshort rangeâ (by which we mean that Vâ(L12)ðsubscriptð¿12V(L_{12}) increases more quickly than L12â(L12+1)subscriptð¿12subscriptð¿121L_{12}(L_{12}+1)). The validity of Jainâs picture also depends upon Vâ(L12)ðsubscriptð¿12V(L_{12}) being of short range. The pseudopotential describing quasiparticles of a Laughlin condensed state display short range behavior only at certain values of L12subscriptð¿12L_{12}. We have used this fact to explain why only certain states in the CF hierarchy give rise to incompressible states of the quasiparticle fluid (or daughter states in the hierarchy). The pseudopotentials Vnâ(L12)subscriptððsubscriptð¿12V_{n}(L_{12}) for higher Landau levels (n>0ð0n>0) do not display short range behavior at all values of L12subscriptð¿12L_{12}, implying that Laughlin-like correlations will not necessarily result at Î½â²=2âp+Î½superscriptðâ²2ðð\nu^{\prime}=2p+\nu, where pðp is an integer and Î½ð\nu is a LaughlinâJain filling factor. The CF ideas have been applied successfully to multicomponent plasmas containing different types of Fermions with the prediction of possible incompressible fluid states for these systems. Finally, the energy spectrum and PL of electronâhole systems can be interpreted in terms of CFâs and Laughlin correlations.
